intro: Secamone schimperiana, commonly known as the African moonflower, is a flowering plant native to southern Africa. It belongs to the Apocynaceae family and is characterized by its showy, night-blooming flowers that are typically white or pale pink. The plant produces a milky sap that contains toxic alkaloids, which can be harmful to humans and animals. It thrives in well-drained soils and prefers full sun to partial shade. The flowers emit a sweet fragrance at night, attracting nocturnal pollinators such as moths.
